patient_information: A 34-year-old man from Phuket, Thailand, presented to a hospital in Germany. He reported a significant weight loss of 7 kg in the last 3 months and on examination was very wasted, with a body mass index of 14 kg/m².
chief_complaint: A 2-week history of fever and a papular rash.
history_of_present_illness: For two weeks, the patient experienced fever and a papular rash affecting his whole body, particularly his face and trunk. This was in the context of a 3-month history of significant weight loss, totaling 7 kg.
exposure_and_epidemiology: The patient lives in Thailand and had arrived in Germany only 3 days prior to presentation to visit friends. Talaromycosis is noted to be endemic to East and South-east Asia.
vitals: On examination, the patient was febrile with a temperature of 38.2°C (100.76°F).
physical_exam: Physical examination revealed a very wasted man with pale conjunctivae. He had a generalized, non-pruritic rash of small umbilicated papules, predominantly on his face and trunk. There was generalized lymphadenopathy, with swollen nodes in the left supraclavicular, inguinal, and axillary regions. Abdominal examination showed hepatosplenomegaly, with the spleen palpable two fingers below the left costal margin and a liver span of 15 cm in the midclavicular line.
labs_and_diagnostics: Initial laboratory results showed pancytopenia with a WBC of 2.1 ×10⁹/L, haemoglobin of 9.8 g/dL, and platelets of 110 ×10⁹/L. The C-reactive protein was elevated at 150 mg/L. An HIV test was positive, and the patient was found to be highly immunosuppressed with a CD4 cell count of 2/µL. Histopathology from a lymph node biopsy showed multiple yeast-like structures and no acid-fast bacilli. Blood cultures, as well as cultures from a skin biopsy and lymph node aspirate, all grew Talaromyces (Penicillium) marneffei.
differential_diagnosis: The differential diagnosis for fever, generalized lymphadenopathy, and hepatosplenomegaly included infectious diseases and neoplasms. Specific considerations were other viral infections like CMV and EBV, disseminated tuberculosis, atypical mycobacteria, melioidosis, and Bartonella spp. (bacillary angiomatosis). Other fungal infections such as cryptococcosis and histoplasmosis were also considered, along with visceral leishmaniasis and neoplasms like lymphoma.
management_and_clinical_course: The diagnosis of talaromycosis was made, and the patient was started on a 2-week course of intravenous liposomal amphotericin B, followed by oral itraconazole. Antiretroviral therapy (ART) was initiated. On 3-week follow-up, he was afebrile and gaining weight. Six months later, he presented with recurrent cervical lymphadenopathy. A relapse of talaromycosis was suspected, but an infection with atypical mycobacteria was found. This was interpreted as an unmasking immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome (IRIS), as his CD4 count had risen to 102/µL with a suppressed viral load.
final_diagnosis: The final diagnosis was disseminated Talaromycosis, caused by the fungus Talaromyces marneffei. This occurred in the setting of severe immunosuppression from a previously undiagnosed HIV infection, confirmed by a positive HIV test and a CD4 count of 2/μL. The diagnosis was established by the isolation of T. marneffei from cultures of blood, skin, and lymph node tissue, supported by histopathology showing yeast-like structures.
